texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One question I hear quite often is "how do I add IP aliases in FreeBSD?" It's not terribly intuitive, but you can follow these steps:
texts.text: One question I hear quite often is "how do I add IP aliases in FreeBSD?" It's not terribly intuitive, but you can follow these steps:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Add it to /etc/rc.conf first (so you don't forget). In this example, we have a Realtek card called rl0:
texts.text: Add it to /etc/rc.conf first (so you don't forget). In this example, we have a Realtek card called rl0:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
ifconfig_rl0="inet 192.168.1.5 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias0="inet 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias1="inet 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias2="inet 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0"
texts.text:
ifconfig_rl0="inet 192.168.1.5 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias0="inet 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias1="inet 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias2="inet 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: UBER-IMPORTANT NOTE:  Start with the number 0 (zero) any time that you make IP alias configurations in /etc/rc.conf.
texts.text: UBER-IMPORTANT NOTE:  Start with the number 0 (zero) any time that you make IP alias configurations in /etc/rc.conf.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
ifconfig_rl0="inet 192.168.1.5 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias1="inet 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias2="inet 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias3="inet 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0"
texts.text:
ifconfig_rl0="inet 192.168.1.5 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias1="inet 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias2="inet 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0"
ifconfig_rl0_alias3="inet 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you do it the wrong way (which means starting alias with anything but alias0), only the primary comes up. Keep that in mind.
texts.text: If you do it the wrong way (which means starting alias with anything but alias0), only the primary comes up. Keep that in mind.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can do things the extraordinarily dangerous way:
texts.text: You can do things the extraordinarily dangerous way:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Or, you can follow the recommended steps:
texts.text: Or, you can follow the recommended steps:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0
texts.text:
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.10 netmask 255.255.255.0
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.15 netmask 255.255.255.0
# ifconfig rl0 alias 192.168.1.20 netmask 255.255.255.0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Any good system administrator knows to test things once their configured. Make sure to ping your new IP's from a source on your network and outside your network (if possible/applicable).
texts.text: Any good system administrator knows to test things once their configured. Make sure to ping your new IP's from a source on your network and outside your network (if possible/applicable).
